Notes: Чтобы переназначить действие, щёлкните по текущему варианту, затем нажмите новую кнопку, к которой вы хотите привязать это действие.
Nynorsk: For å endra knappen til ei handling; trykk på elementet, og so trykkjer ein på den knappen ein vil nytta til vald handling.

Notes: Kill a rabbit in your hands

English: An improvised knife made of scrap metal with a cloth-wrapped handle. Not as robust or nice to look at as one made by a professional, but it'll do the trick.
Nynorsk: Ein kniv laga av skrapmetall med eit handtak surra inn av tøy. Ikkje so robust eller fin å sjå på som knivar laga av profesjonelle, men hen gjer jobben.

English: Sharp piece of scrap metal that broke off your plane. Makes a good improvised knife.
Nynorsk: Eit skarpt metallstykke frå flyet ditt. Kantil nauds nyttast som ein kniv.

English: Bladed tools like the Knife and Hatchet wear out as you use them. Sharpening Stones let you keep them in working condition, but are rare and have limited uses so conserve them.
Nynorsk: Reiskap som knivar og økser vert sløve med nytt. Med eit bryne kan du halde reiskapa i god stand, men du finn dei ikkje kvar som helst og kan berre nyttast so mykje, so nytt det med måte.

English:
Blackrock’s establishment as a maximum-security incarceration complex is a mixture of truth, legend, and good old-fashioned hyperbole. But its founding is without question bound up with the history of Great Bear Island.

Local communities, almost as a rule, steer clear of the Penitentiary. Whether that is due to reasonable caution or unreasonable fear, no one can say.

There are still others who claim that nothing can match the harshness of winter living on Great Bear, and that Islanders should feel secure in their own hardy resilience. They are tougher than any prison inmate.

Little is known about Blackrock Penitentiary’s original architect, G.W. Jahnn. A pipe organ builder and designer by trade, he switched to institutional design after emigrating to Canada in the late 19th Century.

In terms of his design influences, the official records only note his intense interest in Egyptian monuments, British social theorist Jeremy Bentham, and a somewhat peculiar fascination with the music and astronomy of ancient Greece.

All in all, his work, and the prison itself, make for a remarkable and unusual contribution to the rugged landscape of Great Bear Island.

Nothing in Blackrock’s design could outweigh the influence of the surrounding landscape on the mission of the Penitentiary. The rugged valley surrounding the prison grounds has always been itself a secondary deterrent.

Before the first stone was laid for the Penitentiary, gold miners and prospectors made their way to the region to try their hand at finding fortune in the shadow of Blackrock Mountain. Many died, and few found the gold they were looking for.

Still, it’s said the many streams and rivers that surround the prison grounds still carry gold, even in winter.

Sentenced to 20 years at the notorious Blackrock Penitentiary, Great Bear Island was the end of the road for the unsavory convict, and he knew it. A cowardly man, Hobbs loved chaos. And even with a knife in his belly, he was still stirring up trouble.

In the 1960s, a small hydroelectric dam was built on the Carter River. The project was engineered and financed by industrial magnate, Richard Carter, who intended to use power from the dam to sustain a small town he planned to build for the growing workforce across his mining empire. Unfortunately, a combination of setbacks due to seismic activity (which resulted in several deaths and forced the shutdown of one of his mines) and a drop in the price of coal and copper in the late 1960s bankrupted Carter, who abandoned the nearly completed project. In the 1980s, there were multiple attempts to modernize Carter Dam and bring it back online, but by then changes to the local climate and the hydrodynamics of the Mystery Lake area, as well as external public pressure in support of the newly minted Mystery Lake Provincial Park, resulted in Carter Dam being shut down for good in the late 1990s. Labour disputes and early eco-activism by a small group of environmentalists -- billing themsjølves the "Forest Talkers" -- resulted in the sudDen closure of the dam, primarily for the employee’s safety. A skeleton crew of maintenance workers were actually trapped in the Dam for days until mediators could extract them. No violence was reported, but the event served to galvanize the Forest Talkers, who felt their success in keeping Carter Dam shut down validated their continued work to protect Great Bear’s further development and exploitation.
Nynorsk: På 1960-talet blei det bygd ein liten hydroelektrisk demning på Carter-elva. Prosjektet blei utvikla og finansiert av industrimagnaten Richard Carter, som hadde til hensikt å nytta demningen til å levera straum til ein liten by han hadde tenkt å byggja til den aukande arbeidsstyrken i gruveimperiet hans. Uheldigvis gjorde ein kombinasjon av tilbakeslag på grunn av seismisk aktivitet (som førte til fleire dødsfall og tvangsnedlegging av ein av Carter sine gruver) og eit fall i prisen på kol og kopar på slutten av sekstitalet at Carter gjekk konkurs og derfor skrinla det nesten ferdigstilte prosjektet. På åttitalet blei det gjort fleire forsøk på å modernisera Carter-demningen og varetake ein stabil drift, men endringar i det lokale klimaet og hydrodynamikken i Løyndomsvatnet, og dessutan aukande støtte i befolkninga til det nyleg lanserte «Løyndomsvatnet parkområde», resulterte i at Carter-demningen blei stengt for godt på slutten av 1990-talet. Bak den plutselege nedlegginga av demningen – det blei sagt at det var for å varetake arbeidarane sin sikkerheit – lå arbeidskonfliktar og tidleg økoaktivisme utført av ei lita gruppe miljøvernarar som kalte seg «Skogpratarane». Ei lita gruppe vedlikehaldsarbeidarar blei faktisk sittande fast i demningen i fleire dagar før mellommenn fekk henta dei ut. Det ble ikkje rapport om voldsbruk, men hendinga eggja Skogpratarane, som følte at suksessen med å få Carter-demningen stengt var ein bekreftelse på at arbeidet deiras med å beskytte Sværebjørn mot vidare utbygging og utnytting.

English:
Founded in 1911 during the early rush to mine coal in the surrounding mountains, Milton went through a boom/bust cycle throughout the 1900s, at one point peaking at about 1000 residents. In the 2000s, it settled into the 100s, and Post-Collapse, the population has struggled to remain in the low double digits. Originally built along a supply route from the coastline leading into the interior, the old dirt path was replaced by a paved highway in 1960. It’s location about halfway between Port Mary and the interior mountains gave it a natural advantage as a convenient stopping off point for fuel and supplies for miners, loggers, mill workers, and campers from the Mainland, a dynamic that fueled the town’s growth as the Island’s economy boomed in the 1980s. However, the construction of the Great Bear Highway (AKA Highway 15) meant travellers could easily bypass Milton on their way North, which in many ways triggered the gradual decline of Milton’s importance as a gateway town.
  
 This decline was exaggerated even more in the Post-Collapse economic environment, where very few travellers or resource workers had reason to visit Great Bear. Eventually, apart from a few stalwarts and old-timers with deep roots in the area, Milton became, for all intents and purposes, a ghost town.
Nynorsk:
Milton vart skipa i 1911 under det fyrste kapplaupet for å utvinna kol i fjella i området, og gjennom heile 1900-talet opplevde byen ein syklus av oppturar og nedturar. På sitt høgaste var innbyggjartalet omtrent 1000. På 2000-talet stabiliserte tallet seg på nokon hundre, men etter sammenbrotet har innbyggjartalet knapt haldt seg tosifra. I 1960 blei den gamle grusvegen, som opprinneleg blei anlagt som forsyningsruta frå kysten til innlandet, erstatta med ein asfaltert veg. Fordi Milton legg halvvegs mellom Port Mary og fjella lenger inn gjorde byen til ein naturleg og praktisk stoppestad for gruvearbeidarar, tømmerhoggarar, tresliparar og teltturistar som trengte drivstoff og forsyninger på veg frå fastlandet. Byen sin vekst auka i takt med øya sin økonomiske oppblomstring på åttitallet. Men sidan ble det anlagt ein ny veg, Sværebjørn motorveg (motorveg 15), og med den kunne reisande lett køyra utenom Milton på veg nordover. Dette førte etter kvart til at Milton mista sin status som ein viktig stoppestad.
  
Nedgongen skaut ytterlegar fart etter Sammenbrotet, då den økonomiske situasjonen gjorde at det var få reisande eller arbeidarar som fant nokon grunn til å besøke Sværebjørn. Til slutt blei Milton, med unntak av nokon få hardhausar og eldre mennesker, i realiteten ein spøkelsesby.

English:
The Mystery Lake region is an Alpine valley, average altitude of 1200 meters above sea level, named for the large lake that dominates its South-Eastern quadrant. The region is fringed by mountains on the West and South, and the foothills of the Inner Island Range to the North and East. The region is bisected by a section of the North-South line of the Trans-Island Railway.

The region’s main characteristics are its heavily forestad and hilly terrain, as well as abundance of wildlife. The region’s high altitude leads to low average temperatures, as well as some of the coldest night-time temperatures on Great Bear Island. Heavy snowfalls are common.

The Mystery Lake area is a popular Summer-time destination with campers and hikers, but the area largely shuts down during the Winter months due to its inaccessibility: there are no major roads connecting the area to the more populated regions in the adjoining valleys lower in the mountain chain, so the area is primarily accessed by dedicated hikers willing to make the long trek that winds along medium to advanced-level trails, from the nearest town of Rupert’s Landing.

The region’s harsh inaccessibility has been both a blessing and a curse over the years. Until the railway line was blastad through in the 1930s, the area was largely a pristine and untouched wilderness, but the lack of amenities or a standing population made it difficult for any real permanent infrastructure to take root. A project to link the Mystery Lake area with a secondary highway network criss-crossing between the various mountain valleys was abandoned due to the geological instability of the steep mountains and cliffs the highway caused landslides that were a continuous threat to the project’s viability, and the highway project was abandoned after only a few kms of roadway had been cleared.

In the 1960s, ambitious industrialist Richard Carter selected the Mystery Lake area for a new hydro-electric project, meant to provide power to a large mining operation in the next valley. The lake’s continuous replenishment by a vibrant aquafir network as well as mountain streams that channeled annual Spring runoff, made Mystery Lake a natural reservoir with untapped hyrdo-electric potential. Yet other than a small test dam constructed in 1962, this project was abandoned when the region’s inaccessibility and seismic instability made it cost-prohibitive.

To this day, apart from the railway line that passes through, the only connection between the Mystery Lake region and the adjoining valleys are the hiking trails that pass through the mountains. These trails often become impassable during the Winter months, due to cold temperatures and heavy snowfall. Also, due to the region’s generally uninhabited nature, wildlife have not become habituated to the presence of humans, which can make them threatening. Hikers and campers are warned to avoid the area during the Winter months, as well as to store all food and waste in “bear safe” containers.
Nynorsk:
Regionen som går under namnet Løyndomsvatnet, er ein dal kor gjennomsnittshøgda over havet er 1200 meter. Området har fått sitt namn etter den store innsjøen som dominerer den sørauststlege kvadranten. Regionen grensar mot fjell i vest og i sør, og mot lågberga til øya sin indre fjellkjede i nord og i aust. Regionen er delt i to av nord-sør-linja til jernbaneselskapet på øya.

Det som fyrst og fremst kjenneteiknar regionen, er dei svære skogane og det kuperte terrenget, samt det rike dyrelivet. Regionen ligg høgt over havet, og dette gjev låge gjennomsnittstemperaturar og ikkje minst nokon av dei kaldaste nattetemperaturane på Sværebjørn. Det er vanleg med mykje snø.

Løyndomsvatnet er eit populært reisemål for teltturistar og turgåarar om sommaren, men om vinteren er området so vanskeleg å nå at det i prinsippet er isolert. Det er ingen større veger som knytt området til dei meir befolka naboregionene i dalane lenger ned i fjellkjeda, so dei fleste som kjem innom, er innbitte turgåarar som er villige til å ta den lange turen langs dei krevande turstiane frå Rupertshamn, den nærmaste byen.

Regionen sin utilgjengelegheit har vert både ein velsignelse og ein forbannelse opp gjennom åra. Til jernbanelinja sprengte seg gjennom fjella i 1930-åra bestod området for det meste av vill og urørt natur, og mangelen på fasilitetar og fastbuande gjorde det vanskeleg for permanent infrastruktur å slå rot. Ein plan om å knytte Løyndomsvatnet til eit sekundært nettverk av riksveier som gjekk mellom dei ulike dalane, blei skrinlagt på grunn av dei geologisk ustabile bratte fjella og klippene i området. Bygginga av vegen førte til jordskred som trua lønsemda til prosjektet, og det var ikkje vorte rydda mange kilometer før heile vegprosjektet blei avblåst.

På 1960-talet valde den ambisiøse industrimagnaten Richard Carter Løyndomsvatnet då han skulle starta opp eit nytt hydroelektrisk prosjekt som var meina å levera straum til eit stort gruveanlegg i nabodalen. Det at innsjøen kontinuerleg fekk påfyll både frå eit energisk akvifernettverk og fjellbekkane som leia det årlege smeltevatnet om våren, gjorde Løyndomsvatnet til eit naturlig vassmagasin med uutnytta hydroelektrisk potensial. Men med unntak av ein liten prøvedemning som blei anlagt i 1962, blei prosjektet skrinlagt då den dårlige tilgjengelegheit til regionen og dei ustabile seismiske forholda gjorde at det ikkje var lønsamt.

Til den dag i dag er den einaste forbindelsen – bortsett frå jernbanen – mellom Løyndomsvatnet og nabodalane turstiane over fjella. Desse turstia vert nærmast umoglege å fylgja om vinteren på grunn av låge temperaturar og mykje snø. Som fylgje av regionen sine låge innbyggjartal har dyrelivet dessutan ikkje vent seg til folk, og dette kan gjera dei truande. Turgåarar og teltturistar advarast mot å begi seg inn i området i vintermånadane, og blir bedd dessutan om å oppbevara all mat og avfall i «bjørnesikre» behaldarar.
Her var det ein gong nokon møller.

English: In the mid-20XX, the ongoing global economic crisis, fueled by continued political instability in the US and Europe, contributing to increasing volatility in the financial markets, led to the sudDen catastrophic collapse of the Canadian, and in general, the North American banking system. This immediately rendered Canadian currency worthless, triggered super-inflation of the US dollar, and all trade and economic activity promptly shifted to the Chinese Yuan or crypto-currencies (a la Bitcoin). Crippled economically, Canada was brought under the financial oversight of the North American Economic Zone, which positioned Canada as a kind of protectorate of a larger US-based economic bloc. From this point onward, the majority of economic activity became centralized on Canada’s already densely urbanized population, with smaller rural and remote communities being essentially cut off. Without a local economic lifeline many of these communities had become dependent on for their continued existence, most rural or remote communities became hollowed out, as people fled to urban areas in search of greater economic stability.
Nynorsk: I 20XX førte den pågåande globale økonomiske krisa, godt hjelpen av eit vedvarende ustabilt politisk klima i USA og Europa som bidrog til endå større svingningar i finansmarknadane, til ein plutselig kollaps i fyrst og fremst det kanadiske, men òg det amerikanske banksystemet. Kanadisk valuta blei straks verdilaus, Amerikanske dollar gjennomgjekk ein superinflasjon, og all handel og anna økonomisk aktivitet blei umiddelbart flytta over til kinesiske yuan eller kryptovalutaer som Bitcoin. Canada, som økonomisk låg med knekt rygg, blei underlagt den Nord-Amerikanske økonomiske sone, som gav Canada status som eit slags protektorat av ein større USA-basert økonomisk blokk. Frå no av blei det meste av økonomisk aktivitet sentralisert i Canada sitt allereie tett befolka byområder, medan landsbygda og fjerntliggjande samfunn i all hovedsak blei isolert. Utan den lokale økonomien som folk hadde støtta seg til for å overleva, blei landsbygda og dei fleste småstadane tømt for folk, som flokka til byane på jakt etter betre økonomisk stabilitet.

English: KNOWLEDGE: History of The Collapse, Part One

For places like Great Bear, already quite remote and suffering after decades of economic decline, the sudDen Collapse was the final straw. Without any major local economic drivers of their own, the remaining communities on Great Bear became completely dependent on a supply lifeline from the Mainland -- regular shipments of basic staples designed to keep them alive: fuel, food, medical supplies, etc., in many ways, akin to WW2-era wartime rationing. In exchange for regular supply drops, the “Mainlanders” -- in some cases, at the behest of their economic overlords South of the border -- felt justified in taking whatever supplies and raw materials they needed to maintain the urban communities, including dismantling some of the heavy industrial infrastructure left on Great Bear.
Nynorsk: For plassar som Sværebjørn, som låg langt utanfor allmannveg og allereie sleit etter fleire tiår med nedgongstider, var Samanbrotet dråpen som fekk begeret til å flyta over. Utan store lokale hyrnesteinsbedriftar blei dei resterande samfunna på øya fullstendig avhengig av forsyningar frå fastlandet, med regelmessige forsendelser av det mest naudsynte for å halde seg i live, som drivstoff, medisinske forsyningar osv. På mange måter minnet det om rasjoneringa under andre verdskrig. I bytte mot dei regelmessige forsyningsleveransane synast «fastlendingane» – nokon gonger på befaling frå overherrane sør for grensa – det berre var rett og rimeleg at dei kunne forsyna seg av dei ressursane og råmateriala dei trengte for å oppretthalde sine urbane samfunn, og dei demonterte òg noko av tungindustrien sin resterande infrastruktur på Sværebjørn.

English: KNOWLEDGE: History of The Collapse, Part Two

Unhappy with their growing dependence on the Mainland for economic support, as well as the Mainlander’s continued view that Great Bear exists solely as a resource clearinghouse for their benefit, some people who chose to remain on Great Bear decided to engage their self-sufficiency. Small-scale local food production efforts, akin to the Victory GarDen program of WW2 England and Canada, sprouted up all over Great Bear, with individuals and even communities taking it in their own hands to produce food and power resources. Some of these activities took on an aspect of being politically or even ideologically motivated -- these weren’t just gardens or small-scale attempts to provide for local needs. These were acts of rebellion against a (perceived?) occupying economic force.
Nynorsk: Nokon av innbyggjarane som valde å vera igjen på Sværebjørn, var misnøgde med at øya blei meir avhengig av økonomisk stytte frå fastlandet, og at fastlendingane fortsette å sjå på heimplassen deiras som berre ein ressurskilde dei kunne utnytta, so dei prøvde å gjera seg meir sjølvforsynte. Små matproduksjonsinitiativer, à la «Victory Garden»-programma i England og Canada under andre verdskrig, begynte å spretta opp over heile Sværebjørn, og både enkeltpersonar og til og med heile samfunn tok ansvar med å produsera mat og kraft. Nokon av aktivitetane fekk etter kvart karakter av å vera politisk eller til og med ideologisk motivert, altså noko meir enn berre ein hage eller spede forsøk på å varetaka lokale behov. Initiativene var eit ledd i eit opprør mot ein (innbilt?) økonomisk okkupasjonsmakt.

English: KNOWLEDGE: History of The Collapse, Part Three

Cut off from the Mainland -- economically and figuratively -- Great Bear Islanders became increasingly segregated into two pseudo-political entities along ideological lines: those who gratefully embraced dependence on the Mainland and viewed the regular supply ships as a charitable gesture in apology for the Mainland’s exploitation of Great Bear’s resource riches, and those who sought ultimate independence and who considered trade and travel between the Mainland to be a necessary evil, viewing Mainlanders with a degree of mistrust. Those in support of the Mainlanders even considered the small-scale “Victory Garden” type activities as a sign of lacking patriotism, a concept that hadn’t really existad as such in the Canadian mindset, pre-Collapse.
Nynorsk: Avskåret frå fastlandet – både økonomisk og i overført betydning – delte øyfolket på Sværebjørn i større grad seg inn i to kvasipolitiske grupperingar langs ein ideologisk skillelinje: dei som med takksemd omfavna avhengigheita til fastlandet og såg på forsyningsskipa som ein godgjerande gest og unnskyldning for fastlandets utnytting av naturressursane på Sværebjørn, og dei som ynskte å vera fullstendig uavhengig og såg på handel og reise mellom øya og fastlandet som eit naudsynt onde, og som gjerna var mistru imot fastlendingar. Dei som støtta fastlendingene, såg på sjølv små initiativer av «Victory Garden»-typen som eit teikn på manglande patriotisme, eit konsept som eigentleg ikkje hadde eksistert i det canadiske tankesettet før Samanbrotet.

English: KNOWLEDGE: History of the Collapse, Part Four

Pleasant Valley’s harsh and remote location, even for Great Bear Island, has shaped much of its history and the character of its residents. The Vallley’s geography -- wide, open fields ringed by jagged mountain ranges -- creates unusually strong weather events. Locals have long told of multi-day storms, high winds, and a deep, endless cold during the Winter months.
But these conditions didn’t keep Great Bear Islanders from settling there. In fact, some saw the Valley’s wild and desolate hills as an ideal place to homestead.

Founded in 1919, Thomson’s Crossing remains the only significant community in Pleasant Valley. With a history tied to the farming and mining concerns of its residents, the isolated town followed its own path along the boom and bust cycle of Great Bear Island industry. 
With greater and greater instability due to seismic activity, the workings in the nearby mines proved too dangerous for later generations to exploit. And with the arrival of local activists, determined to keep new industry from taking root in Pleasant Valley, Thomson’s Crossing began its steady decline.

With the onset of The Collapse, Pleasant Valley locals didn’t notice the brunt of change all that quickly. Being so accustomed to remote living already, it took several years before life shifted in any dramatic fashion. 
Residents did begin to notice the growing scarcity of the few creature comforts imported to the Island. But connected as they were through regular reports from the regional weather service radio station, their post-Collapse isolation took some years to set in.

Nynorsk: Du trur det ikkje før du får sjå det.

English: Information leaflet containing information about the Great Bear Island presented by the Great Bear Historical Society.
A key for one of the Mystery Lake cabins
Nynorsk: Ein nykel til ein av hyttene ved Løyndomsvatnet.

English: A key for one of the Mystery Lake cabins
Nynorsk: Ein nykel til ein av hyttene ved Løyndomsvatnet.

English: A key for one of the Mystery Lake cabins
Nynorsk: Ein nykel til ein av hyttene ved Løyndomsvatnet.

English: A piece of paper, wet from the snow. The handwriting is fading, but legible.

Papa,
When the lights came, we had to leave. We thought you might stop here, on your old trail, but we couldn’t wait. The hunting is good, just like we remembered. Should be even better for you. If you find this, rest a while. We’ll be waiting on the coast.
Eliza
A letter found in one of the Mystery Lake campground cabins.
Nynorsk: Eit brev funne i ein av hyttene ved Løyndomsvatnet.

English: Gå inn i alle bygg i både Løyndomsvatnet og Kystvegen (i eit spel).
Nynorsk: Me har eigentleg ikkje lov til å fare der utanfor sesongen, men det er glimrande jaktmoglegheitar i nærleiken av Løyndomsvatnet. Oppsynsmannen stenger vanlegvis parken for vinteren. Hyttene er menit for bruk om sommaren, so ta med varme klede og ein god sovepose. Vi bryt oss inn, skyter eit par hjortar og frakter kjøtet ut om eit par veker. Stan vil plukka oss opp langs Kystvegen. Møt meg ved hyttene den XX. november. Kom åleina. Ta med øl. Det pågår tømmerhogst i området, so hald deg ute av syne.

English: A page from a notebook with a few handwritten lines.

All I see are wolves. Not sure what happened.
I don’t like it, but if this keeps up I’ll do what I gotta do, like always. 
Wolves do the same, anyways. Got to keep movin'. Can't get backed into a corner again.
Notes:
Вокруг одни волки. Не знаю, что случилось.
Мне это не нравится, но если ничего не изменится, придётся делать то, что необходимо. Как всегда. 
Волки поступают так же. Нужно постоянно двигаться, иначе меня снова загонят в угол.

Nynorsk: Vanlige skinnsko som tek seg godt ut på byen, men som kan bety dauden her ute. Forhåpentleg har du varme labbar!

Nynorsk: Mindre enn ein time av nattemørkeret igjen

English: The stack of letters Jeremiah wants you to burn. Who could a reclusive trapper be writing to out here? In any case, you shouldn't read other people's mail.

English: A simple winter coat constructed using modern materials. Good weight to warmth ratio.
Nynorsk: Ein enkel vinteranorakk laga av moderne materialar. Gjev god varme i jamført med vekta.

English: A light outer layer meant to protect from wind and water. Has no real warmth value of its own, but useful when paired with a decent under layer.
Nynorsk: Ei lett ytterjakke som vernar mot vind og vayn. Har ingen eigentleg varmeverdi på eiga hand, men nyttig i kombinasjon med skikkelig undertøy.

English: Higher quality means more detailed objects in the distance, at the expense of performance.
Nynorsk: Høgare kvalitet betyr meir detaljerte ting i bakgrunnen, men dårlegere yting.

Nynorsk: Eg har utforska {%-value} % av verda so langt
Eg har vert på desse plassane

English: Heavy wool jacket with a decidedly Canadian flavour. Beloved by hunters and lumberjacks alike.
Nynorsk: Tung ulljakke som osar av Canada. Ein favoritt av både jegerar og skogsarbeidar.

English: A magnifying lens that can be used to start a fire during daylight.
Nynorsk: Ei lupe som kan nyttast til å laga eld i dagsljos.

indicates when the map was last updated
indicates when the map was last updated
indicates when the map was last updated
indicates when the map was last updated

English: Freshly harvestad maple sapling. Needs to be cured before it can be used for crafting and repair.
Nynorsk: Nyhogd ungtre av sorten løn. Må tørkast før han kan nyttast til å vøla og laga ting.

English: Small maple sapling that has been cured. Can be used for crafting and repair.
Nynorsk: Turka ungtre av sorten løn. Kan nyttast til å vøla og laga ting.

English: Thick and sweet, this high-calorie condiment is an excellent source of energy. Pancakes not included.
Nynorsk: Tjukk og søt saus proppfull av energi. Pannekaker ikkje inkuldert.

Notes: Making a charcoal map of the area you can see around you.
Represents a map location that hasn't been explored, so its name is unknown.

English:
(Not Available In Alpha)

A simple map that shows obvious known landmarks. 
It will be updated with Knowledge as you 
explore the world.
Nynorsk:
(Ikkje tilgjengeleg i Alpha)

Eit enkelt kart som visar kjende landemerke. 
Det oppdaterast etter kvart som du utforskar omgevnadane.

English: Heavy wool coat designed for seafaring types. Not the warmest coat out there, but close to it. Does a good job of blocking the wind but gets very heavy when wet. Stylish.
Nynorsk: Tung ullfrakk laga for sjømenn. Ikkje verdens varmaste frakk, men heller ikkje langt vekke. Gjev god vern mot vind, men vert svært tung når han vert våt. Stilig.

Notes: Marsh location, smalll group of ruined cabins
Marsh location, a group of derailed train cars
Marsh location, old, abandoned, ruined farmstead
Marsh location, high viewpoint overlooking the marsh

English: Explore the world to find the route that leads to this region!
Nynorsk: Utforsk omgjevnadane for å finna vegen til denne regionen!

English:
For advanced players. A frigid open marshland bisected by a railway line. Weak ice and constant winds make this area highly dangerous.

Connects to Mystery Lake.
Nynorsk: For avanserte spelarar. Eit aude og open våtmark delt i to av ei jernbanelinje. Tynn is og konstant vind gjer området særs farleg. Er forbundet med Løyndomsvatnet.

Notes: Marsh location, large ridge overlooking marsh (safe, secluded area)

English: Transmitter covers Forlorn Muskeg, Broken Railroad, and Bleak Inlet Regions

Notes: Marsh location, waterfall (water comes from Milton River)

English: A pie any meateater would love. Lunchbox-ready.
A thick and greasy stew filled to the brim with harvested meats. Fuel for a long day in the woods.

Notes: first aid supplies box found in hangar
this is a noun, not an action. refers to snow that is currently being melted
a small industrial box used for controlling machinery, discared and broken
Metal pot/pan used for cooking food
Metal pot used for cooking food

English:
Ancient in appearance, Methuselah’s clear eyes suggest a deep wisdom and he radiates strength rather than frailty. He has the calm, knowing authority of someone who’s seen a few things in his time.
Methuselah appears to know more than he’s letting on about the events on Great Bear Island.
Contemporary MRE, good quality, and meets all technical requirements to be considered real food! designed to keep a soldier on their feet.
Nynorsk: Moderne feltrasjon. God kvalitet og oppfyller alle dei tekniske krava for å reknast som ekte mat! Laga for å halde ein soldat på beina.

English: Winter version of the traditional coat used by the military. Doesn't use the best technical materials, but is tough as hell. Takes a beating, as you can while wearing it.
Nynorsk: Vinterutgåva av militæret si tradisjonelle jakke. Ikkje laga av dei beste tekniske materialane, men enormt slitesterk. Tålar ein støyt, i likskap med deg om du går med han.

English: A letter containing the whereabouts of a hidDen cache
Nynorsk: Eit brev som fortel kvar du kan finna ein skylt oppbevaring.

English: A letter containing the whereabouts of a hidDen cache
Nynorsk: Eit brev som fortel kvar du kan finna ein skylt oppbevaring.

Notes: Found in cave near road area.

English: A letter found on a discarded backpack in a cave.
Nynorsk: Eit brev funne i ein etterlata ransel i ei hole.

English:
"I left with the others but the storm turned bad and I couldn't keep up. Some turned back to see if they could wait it out at the old Church. I kept going but I think I took a wrong turn. I'll backtrack in the morning and see if I can find their trail."
 
 The letter is signed: "Alice"
Nynorsk:
Eg for samen med dei andre, men stormen auka i styrke, og eg klarte ikkje å halde følgje. Nokon snudde for å venta i den gamle kyrkja. Eg fortsatte, men eg trur eg valde feil veg. Eg går attende i morgon tidleg og ser om eg kan finna ut kva vei dei tok.
 
 Brevet er signert «Alice».

English: Handwritten letter. Blotchy ink suggests whoever wrote it did so while crying.
Nynorsk: Handskriven brev. Flytande blekk, forfatteren grein då brevet vart skriven.

English: "I don't want to do this but I don't have a choice. I just can't stay in Milton anymore. It's just too...empty, and sad. I know I promised to stick with you through thick and thin, but I never signed up for this. I'm sorry. I'll send food when I get to the mainland. I hear they have more there. Love, N."
Nynorsk: Eg har ikkje lyst til å gjera dette, men eg har ikkje noko val. Eg kan ikkje vera i Milton lenger. Det er berre for … tomt og stussleg. Eg veit eg lovte å vera ved di side gjennom tjukt og tynt, men dette hadde eg ikkje forventa. Beklagar. Eg skal sende mat når eg har nådd fastlandet. Eg høyrer dei har meir der. Klem frå N.

Notes: Found in a vehicle parked outside the bank.

English: Quick note scratched on the back of a scrap of paper.
Nynorsk: Ein kort beskjed, skribla ned på ein papirbete.

English: "I left him like I promised I would, and I waited here like you asked. Where are you? It's getting too cold to sit here. Pick me up at the old PO when you can and let's get out of here. If you don't pick me up by midnight, I'm out of here on my own."
Nynorsk: Eg forlét han som eg lovte eg skulle, og venta her, som du ba meg om. Kvar er du? Det byrjar å verta for kaldt til å sitte her. Hent meg ved det gamle postkontoret når du kan, so stikk me her i frå. Dukkar du ikkje opp før midnatt, fer eg på eiga hand.

English: A weathered-looking Milton & Area Parks Board Notice, pinned to the board. Looks like it's been here a while.
Nynorsk: Eit vêrbiten oppslag på tavla til Milton & Omland Parkvesen. Ser ut til å ha hengt der ei stund.

English: Due to the unfortunate accident, the Milton & Area Parks Board can no longer condone the use of the climbing area within the park boundaries. Additionally, recent seismic activity has brought the safety of several some common routes and climbing sections into question. We are reviewing safety policies and will publish findings as soon as possible. Until then, please refrain from using designated climbing areas in the Park. - Signed, M. Antonides, Milton & Area Parks Board.
Nynorsk:
På grunn av den tragiske ulukka kan Milton & Omland Parkvesen ikkje lenger tillate bruk av klatreområdet i parkområdet. I tillegg har den seismiske aktiviteten sådd tvil om sikkerheita til fleire av turløypene og klatrestada våre, og me vil offentleggjera funna våre so snart det er mulig. Til då er ferdsel i parken sitt anviste klatreområder stengt. 

Signert av M. Antonides, Milton & Omland Parkvesen.

English: Information found on store notice board
Nynorsk: Informasjon funne på oppslagstavla i butikken.

English: General Notice to Orca Gas locations on Great Bear Island. As we are no longer in a position to ensure adequate and timely supply deliveries from our mainland distribution centres, we regret to inform you that we must reduce the frequency of our supply deliveries to once per quarter. As such, we are relaxing restrictions on using local suppliers. This applies to our remote locations *only*. All Orca Gas locations on the mainland must continue to source their merchandise from approved providers.
Nynorsk: Generell beskjed til Staurkval gassverk avdelingar på Sværebjørn. Sidan me ikkje lenger mottar fullnøyande og presise leveransar frå distribusjonssentra våre på fastlandet, må me dessverre seia at me er naudt til å redusara leveransane våre til ein gong i kvartalet. Derfor lemper me på restriksjonane våre angåande bruk av lokale leverandørar. Dette gjeld berre våre fjerntliggjande avdelingar. Alle Staurkval gassverk avdelingar på fastlandet må fortsette å hente varene sine frå godkjente leverandørar.

English: A posted notice with details on mine operations.

WARNING!
Due to recent funding shortfalls, we've had to carry out additional blasting on Level 2 sooner than expected.

We're aware this may impact air quality containment controls on lower levels.

We only ask that you follow posted guidelines when working in areas of the facility that may be impacted by any noxious vapors.
A page torn from an old mailing.

*NEW OPPORTUNITIES IN URANIUM MARKETS*

Increasing numbers of Canadian mine operators are turning to uranium production. While licensing and weak capital support continue to slow growth in the sector, several ambitious projects are already off the ground. And others wait in the wings.

Regulators are also keen to stamp out unlicensed operations as they surface. But with each new energy crisis, many existing mines are turning to uranium as a way to shore up their core businesses.

You tell him the valves were never designed to take this kind of abuse. It’s just too corrosive.

There’s a limit to what we can keep pumping into the ground here, even the way we do things.

I’m not talking right and wrong here, just basic physics.

It’s a dirty business.
With outstanding waterproofness, these boots are ideal for damp, underground conditions. Resistant to toxic chemicals and pollution.
Nynorsk: Desse skoa er både særs vasstette og kjemikaliebestandig. Eignar seg godt i fuktige holer.

English: Lightweight and durable for long days at the worksite, the Miner’s Helmet offers excellent physical protection at the cost of warmth and exposure to the wind.
Nynorsk: Lett og slitesterk, laga for lange arbeidsdagar i industrien. Vernar godt, men ein held ikkje varmen.

English: A durable, highly-waterproof jacket. Its average warmth allows for flexible operations underground or on the surface. Layer appropriately.
Nynorsk: Ei vasstett og slitesterk jakke laga for industrien. Gjev grei varme, både nedi gruvene og oppe i dagen.

English: Tough, durable pants with excellent physical protection. Function, not fashion.
Nynorsk: Hardfør og slitesterk bukse laga for industrien. Føremålstenleg, ikkje mote.

English:
For advanced players. A Cold War relic of industrial hubris, the Zone is littered with Chemical Hazards and forgotten infrastructure. Its secrets remain hidden by environmental devastation. Prepare yourself, and take care.

Stay above ground and see the remnants, or dive into the deep mine, at your peril.

Connects to Forsaken Airfield and Transfer Pass.

Notes: Displayed for saves that are less than 1 hour old

English: Eating and Drinking Sound FX Filter
Enabling filters out Eating and Drinking sound effects produced by the player.
Nynorsk: Filtrerar vekk ete- og drikkelydar som kjem frå spelaren.

Notes: refers to missions related to the main story of the game

English: Mission Failed - the convicts re-captured MacKenzie
Wool mitts with a reinforced palm. Will keep your fingers nice and toasty.
Nynorsk: Ullvottar, forsterka i handflata. Held fingrane gode og varme.

English: A simple Moose-hide satchel. Lightens the load for a weary traveller.
Nynorsk: Ein enkel sekk laga av elgskinn. Lettar på børda.

English: Cloak crafted from Moose hide. Heavy, but offers significant protection from unfriendly wildlife, and is highly waterproof. A rare trophy.
Nynorsk: Ein frakk laga av elgskinn. Tung, men vernar godt og er særs vasstett. Eit sjeldan trofé.

English: Freshly harvested skin of a Moose.
Nynorsk: Skinn nyleg flådd av ein elg.

English: The skin and fur from a Moose. Can be used for Crafting and Repair.
Nynorsk: Skinnet og pelsen til ein elg. Kan nyttast til laging og bøting.

English: Section of a Moose carcass. Cut from the carcass to make transporation a bit easier. Harvest for usable meat.
Nynorsk: Stykke av eit elgkadaver. Skore av for å gjera det lettare å bera. Gjev deg etandes kjøt.

Displayed when player has more dialogue choices to choose from

English:
For new players. Although deep in decline, Milton still offers many sturdy shelters and plentiful wildlife. But if you leave town for the surrounding hills and fields, beware!

Transmitter covers Mountain Town and Hushed River Valley Regions

English: Manufactured boot inspired by the traditional hunter's footwear. designed for mobility and warmth using leather and fur. You can stay warm and move quickly.
Nynorsk: Fabrikklaga sko inspirert av det tradisjonelle jegerfottøyet. Laga av skinn og pels, laga for å ha god rørsleevne og varme. Du held deg varm og kan bevega deg raskt.

Ideal for new players. A balance between wilderness and man-made shelters, resources, and wildlife.

old, worn out bedroll (not one the player would ever use)
Name of old lady in Milton

English: Armed and paranoid, but a good man.
Nynorsk: Væpna og paranoid, men ein god mann.

English: A lichen found in the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest.
Nynorsk: Ein type lav som finst i dei eldgamle skogane ved stillehavskysten i nordvest.

English: En pakke vannrensetabletter. Kan førebyggja dysenteri. Med ein tablett kan du rense 1 liter forureina vann.
Nynorsk: Ein salve som inneheld strylav. Påførast sår for å førebyggja infeksjon.

English: Sweet carbonated drink. Full of high-fructose corn syrup.
Nynorsk: Søt, kullsyreholdig drykk. Full av maissirup med mykje fruktsukker.

Nynorsk: Er du sikker på at du vil overskrive denne dagboka?

Nynorsk: Du må overskriva ei eksisterende dagbok for å lagra ei ny. Fortsetta?

Nynorsk: Er du sikker på at du vil overskriva det valde spelet? All fremdrift frå den speleøkta vil gå tapt.

English: A bottle of Painkillers. Take it to reduce pain from injuries.
Nynorsk: Ein flaske med smertestillande. Minkar smerte ved skade.

English: Choose your audio output device for the best experience.
Nynorsk: Vel den lydeininga du nyttar deg av for å få den beste moglege lydopplevinga.

English: Stack of now-useless papers. Makes for good Tinder and that's about it.
Nynorsk: Bunke med papir. Godt å laga knusk av, men ikkje mykje meir.

English: Advance time without the benefits of sleep.
Nynorsk: Få tida til å gå utan fordelane ved søvn.

English: A pie filled with sweet, canned peaches. Reminds of warmer seasons and brighter days.
Classic Pancakes, with Peaches. Perfect for a day of climbing.
Jar of creamy peanut butter. Good source of energy.
Nynorsk: Glas med peanøttsmør. Ei bra energikjelde..

English: Rabbit pelt. Can be used for crafting and repair.
Nynorsk: Kaninpels. Kan nyttast til å bøta og laga ting.

For advanced players. A challenging, vast mountain wilderness region with a few key shelters, originally settled by hardy homesteaders.

Connects to Mystery Lake, Coastal Highway, and Timberwolf Mountain.
Notes: REMOVED: You've found your way to Kosedalen, a vast rural-mountain wilderness originally settled by hardy homesteaders.

For særs erfarne spelarar. Eit utfordrande og stort fjellområde med lite ly, fyrst bebodd av iherdige nybyggjarar.

Er forbundet med Løyndomsvatnet, Kystvegen og Vargafjellet.

English: Beans in molasses, with bits of what looks like pork.
Nynorsk: Bønner i melasse, med noko som lignar på svinekjøt.

English: Oats cooked in Water. Sustaining and timeless.
A variety of visual effects used to make the game look better. Reduce quality level to improve performance at the expense of visual quality.
Nynorsk: Eit utval visuelle effektar som gjer at spelet ser betre ut. Reduser kvalitetsnivået for å betre ytinga på kostnad av grafikken.

English: A scrap of paper found in Milton Post Office.
Nynorsk: Ein papirbete funne i Milton postkontor.

English: "Margaret -- we have to stop accepting mail at Milton. We have no way of getting it back to the mainland but we can't tell people that, or they'll know we've been holding on to it all this time. Find some excuse. Whenever you can, encourage people to use email or drone if they can afford it. I'll keep my eyes open for the mail van but I don't hald out high hopes. I imagine Jack probably drove it into a tree again, somewhere way in the back 40. We're likely to never find it back. Damn I should have stopped him from taking the truck while he was on the drink. I'll see what I can do to fix the situation. Hald tight."
Nynorsk: Margaret, me må slutta å ta imot post her. Me har ingen moglegheitar til å få han til fastlandet, men dette kan me ikkje fortelja nokon, for då skjønnar dei at me har holdt på posten heile tida. Finn på ei unnskyldning. Er det mogleg, so oppfordra folk til å nytta e-post eller ei drone om dei har råd. Eg skal halde utkikk etter postbilen, men eg trur håpet er ute. Jack køyrte han sikkert inn i eit tre igjen, ein eller anna plass langt i huttaheiti. Me finn han sikkert aldri igjen. Helvete, eg skulle ha hindra han i å køyre medan han drakk. Eg skal sjå kva eg kan gjera for å rette opp i situasjonen. Berre vent litt.

English: A bloody page torn from Blackrock Penitentiary records.

[Blackrock -- An Oral History, Vol. A]

I helped build Blackrock. Helped bring steel and bricks in from the Mainland.

But we also sourced rock and stone from some quarries at the foot of that big mountain. I guess that’s why we were all there? Blackrock Mountain. There were mining folk all around that valley, so it was easy to find help to put the bones up on that prison. Some died, some would wander off. But we all got paid and the thing got done. Can’t say much for the mean look of the place but we built ‘er strong.

Nice enough place in the summer months, Great Bear, but those winters were evil things, I tell you. Wind came whippin’ down from the mountain, screaming after ya.

[Blackrock -- An Oral History, Vol. B]

My husband got recruited by some old navy buddy of his. This was the early 50s, and we weren’t exactly in a good spot then. As I found out later from some of the other wives, no good road leads to Blackrock.

We had a little cabin in a hamlet a ways away from the prison. A lot of the staff lived nearby, but not all. Some put as much distance between them and the prison as possible. Even when winters made that a tough go when you had a shift.

I tried not to think about what went on up there. It changed my husband, somehow. He was a sweet man, if a little lost and unlucky in his work. Like a lot of men were back then. But our time on Great Bear, at that place, well, it left him sad in a way I can’t explain.

I tended a garden and wrote endless letters to my sisters. That’s how I remember those years. Endless writing, waiting to leave as the seasons passed.

[Blackrock -- An Oral History, Vol. C]

I knew one of the first wardens out there. I cooked for him just like I cooked for the rest of them. Got to know him pretty well, as you do with folks like that. That fellow would throw these questions at me over dinner, “whadda ya think about this, about that.”

I mostly shrugged when he tried this on me. What did I know? But I had been doing the same cooking during the war. I was used to it.

He had a good head on his shoulders. Good enough for those kinds of men anyway. But he had some funny ideas about punishment. Lots of lectures and preaching type-stuff, that the land would fix them, the prisoners I mean. The Blackrock Mountain. That being in that terrible place was their mission. I never understood any of it.

[Blackrock -- An Oral History, Vol. D]

I was in the first group of guards they brought out there. And it was my first job. I was just a kid still, really. Green like the trees on that freezing island.

But that was the point, I think. That place shaped the guards as much as the men they locked up there. Some of us felt sorta locked up too. Right alongside the inmates.

After a few years, I did my bit, shook their hands, and left. That was the last I saw of Blackrock.

English:
"What am I living for and what am I dying for are the same question."  

- Margaret Atwood
Nynorsk:
«Kva eg lev for og kva eg døyr for, er det same spørsmålet.» 

– Margaret Atwood

English:
"It is not the strongest of the species that survives, nor the most intelligent that survives. It is the one that is the most adaptable to change."

- Charles Darwin
Nynorsk:
«Det er ikkje den sterkaste som overlev, heller ikkje den mest intelligente, men den som er best til å tilpasse seg endringar.»

– Charles Darwin

English:
“Extraordinary people survive under the most terrible circumstances and they become more extraordinary because of it.” 

- Robertson Davies
Nynorsk:
«Ekstraordinære mennesker overlev dei fælaste forhold og dei vert endå meir ekstraordinære av den grunn.»

– Robertson Davies

English:
“He knelt among the shadows and felt his isolation bitterly. They were savages it was true; but they were human.” 

- William Golding, Lord of the Flies
Nynorsk:
«Han knelte blant skuggane og kjende hans bittre einsemd. Dei var villdyr, det var sant, men dei var folk.»

– William Golding, Flugedrotten

English:
“He is at home with his solitude as the note reverberating inside a bell.” 

- Peter Heller, The Dog Stars
Nynorsk:
«Han er like foreina med einsemda si som noten som kling i ei klokke.»

– Peter Heller, The Dog Stars

English:
"No one can tell what goes on between the person you were and the person you become. No one can chart that blue and lonely section of hell. There are no maps of the change. You just come out the other side." 

- Stephen King, The Stand
Nynorsk:
«Ingen kan sei kva som skjer mellom den personen du var, og den personen du blir. Ingen kan kartleggja den triste og einsame delen av helvete. Det er ingen kart over endringa. Du berre kjem ut på den andre sida.» 

– Stephen King, The Stand

English:
“You know, I once read an interesting book which said that, uh, most people lost in the wilds, they, they die of shame. Yeah, see, they die of shame. 'What did I do wrong? How could I have gotten myself into this?' And so they sit there and they... die. Because they didn't do the one thing that would save their lives. Thinking.” 

- David Mamet, The Edge
Nynorsk:
«Veit du, ein gong las eg ei interessant bok som sa at, æh, dei fleste som går seg vill i villmarka, døyr av skam. Du skjønner, dei døyr av skam. Kva gjorde eg feil? Korleis endte eeg opp her? Og so sitter dei der... og døyr. Fordi dei ikkje gjorde den eine tingen som kunne ha reddet dei. Å tenka.» 

– David Mamet, The Edge

English:
“The foraging for food and water, the struggle for life in a world without masters, housed in a body that man had made dependent on himself.” 

- Richard Matheson, I Am Legend
Nynorsk:
«Jakta på mat og vatn, kampen for å overleva i ein verDen utan overordna, i ein kropp som mennesket har gjort avhengig av seg sjølv.» 

– Richard Matheson, I Am Legend

English:
“No lists of things to be done. The day providential to itself. The hour. There is no later. This is later. All things of grace and beauty such that one holds them to one's heart have a common provenance in pain. Their birth in grief and ashes.” 

- Cormac McCarthy, The Road
Nynorsk:
«Ingen lister over ting å gjera. Dagens lagnad bestemt av den sjølv. Timen. Det finst ikkje noko seinare. Dette er seinare. Alle ting av ynde og skjønnhet, slik som ein har dei i sitt hjarte, har ein felles byrjing i smerte. Ein fødsel i sorg og oske.» 

– Cormac McCarthy, The Road

English:
"On a long enough time line, the survival rate for everyone drops to zero."

- Chuck Palahniuk
Nynorsk:
«På ein lang nok tidslinje dett overlevingsraten for alle til null.» 

– Chuck Palahniuk

English:
“Extinction is the rule. Survival is the exception.” 

- Carl Sagan
Nynorsk:
«Utrydding er regelen. Overleving er unntaket.» 

– Carl Sagan

English:
“Life is an error-making and an error-correcting process, and nature in marking man's papers will grade him for wisdom as measured both by survival and by the quality of life of those who survive.”

- Jonas Salk
Nynorsk:
«Livet er ein prosess der ein gjer feil og retter dei opp igjen, og når naturen gjev karakter til mennesket, vil den gi skryt både for evna til å overleva og for kvaliteten på livet til dei som overlev.» 

– Jonas Salk

English:
"Sometimes even to live is an act of courage."

- Seneca
Nynorsk:
«Nokon gongar er sjølv det å leve, ei handling som krev mot.» 

– Seneca

English:
"I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life, and see if I could not learn what it had to teach, and not, when I came to die, discover that I had not lived. I did not wish to live what was not life, living is so dear; nor did I wish to practise resignation, unless it was quite necessary. I wanted to live deep and suck out all the marrow of life, to live so sturdily and Spartan-like as to put to rout all that was not life, to cut a broad swath and shave close, to drive life into a corner, and reduce it to its lowest terms." 

- Henry David Thoreau, Walden
Nynorsk:
«Eg gjekk til skogen fordi eg ynskja å leva eit liv i friheit og omhug, for å verta konfrontert med livets essensielle kjensgjerningar og sjå om eg ikkje kunne læra kva det hadde å læra meg, so eg ikkje ved livets slutt skulle oppdaga at eg eigentleg ikkje hadde vært i live. Eg ynskja ikkje å leva eit halvdaudt liv – livet er altfor dyrebart til det. Heller ikkje ynskja eg å dyrke resignasjonen før det var naudsynt. Eg ville leva djupt og heilt og suge all marg ut av livet, leve frimodig og enkelt ved å jage alt det som ikkje var liv, på flukt, ved å skjæra ei bred skåre og la ljåen gå so djupt som mogleg – og trenge livet opp i eit hyrne og redusere det til sin mest nakne form.»

– Henry David Thoreau, Walden

English:
“It is hard to adapt to chaos, but it can be done. I am living proof of that: It can be done” 

- Kurt Vonnegut, Breakfast of Champions
Nynorsk:
«Det er vanskeleg å tilpasse seg kaos, men det kan gjerast. Det er eg eit levende bevis på: det kan gjerast.» 

– Kurt Vonnegut, Breakfast of Champions

You're very new to handguns, and the Revolver remains an awkward tool. You know how to load it, find a target, and fire, but not much else.
You have a little more shooting experience under your belt. You can pick your targets and you know how to keep your Revolver clean enough to fire.
You've become skilled with the Revolver. Your steady hand finds targets reliably and you know how to keep your Revolver in good condition.
You're efficient and deadly with the Revolver. Your shots are clean and effective, especially in defensive situations.

There's little stopping you with a Revolver in your hands. Your stance is strong, your eyes sharp, and your targets always in sight. More than a tool, it's become an extension of your will to survive.

English:
Quick draw sidearm. Out of place in the wilderness, but its light
weight and short barrel allow for a faster aiming action.

A pale green .303 with a custom stock. A trucker's companion and a durable friend on the open road.


Reliable beyond all else.

This .303 extracts a terrible price at distance thanks to its meticulous construction. Missing from the collection of an enigmatic local collector of rare firearms, this weapon is oiled and engraved for purpose.

A legacy at work.

A weathered .303 Rifle covered in epoxy and duct tape. Its patchwork exterior hides an improved firing action. A handy tool when working the various industrial sites and power stations that dot Great Bear Island.

Fragile and deadly, just like its owner.

English: You're very new to firearms, and aren't yet comfortable with using the Rifle. You know how to load it and how to fire it, and you know what end to point at the target, and that's about it.
Nynorsk: Du har knapt teke i eit skytevåpen før, og du er ikkje komfortabel med å nytta børsa. Du veit korleis du ladar og skyter med han, og kva ende du skal peike mot målet, men det er omtrent alt.

English: You have a little more shooting experience under your belt. You're more accurate and you know how to keep your Rifle in working order.
Nynorsk: Du har fått deg litt meir røynsle. Du er meir visshøv, og du veit korleis du held børsa i god stand.

English: You've become skilled with the Rifle. You're able to hit things further away, and you've developed a better feel for how your shots can be most effective. You know how to keep your Rifle in good condition.
Nynorsk: Du er vorte ganske god med børsa. Du treff på lengre avstand, og du har utvikla ein betre kjensle for korleis du skyter meir effektivt. Du veit korleis du held børsa i god stand.

English: You've developed a strong feeling for the Rifle. Your shots hit more often and you take down your targets more reliably. It is your constant companion.
Nynorsk: Du har verkeleg lært deg korleis børsa skal nyttast. Skota dine treff oftare, og du fell måla på ein meir regelmessig basis. Børsa er ein trufast fylgjesmann.

English: When you aim down those sights the world melts away and there's only you, the Rifle, the bullet, and your target. The trigger is death. The trigger is life.
Nynorsk: Når du har dyret i siktet, stengast verda ute, og det er berre du, børsa, skotet og målet. Avtrekkaren er dauden. Avtrekkaren er livet. Veninna di Hel ventar på neste avtrekk.
Børsa har låst seg. Lad om.

English: Although quite old, the Holster's original owner took great care to preserve the leatherwork. Its fine construction reduces the weight of your primary Rifle.

For advanced players. A remote, wind-blown valley known for its sheer cliffs, dense forests, and steep, winding paths. Although devoid of human settlements, it has long been a destination for the area's toughest mountaineers, and may still have a few secrets to reveal.

Notes: savegame version not compatible with game

English:
Survivors, we have made some necessary changes to help future-proof the save system in THE LONG DARK, and to enable you to receive improvements to the game moving forward. As a result, unfortunately current Survival Mode saves WILL NOT work with the game once you download the Update for Part One of TALES FROM THE FAR TERRITORY. This is true even if you do not purchase the Expansion Pass. This change will not impact Feats, Feats progress, Achievements, or WINTERMUTE saves.

Thank you for your understanding.

Notes: New name for our Story Mode

English:
(Not Available In Alpha)
Play the story of bush pilot[D79D03FF] Will Mackenzie[-] as he struggles to survive, crashed in the wilderness in the aftermath of a mysterious geomagnetic disaster.
(Season One - Ep. 1-?)
Nynorsk:
(Ikkje tilgjengeleg i Alpha)

(Sesong 1 – Episode 1–?)

English: A murderous gang of escaped convicts has captured Mackenzie. Desperate to escape one of the darkest corners of Great Bear Island, he must somehow survive his fiercest enemy yet. Can Mackenzie recover the Hardcase, continue his search for Astrid, and also save the innocents caught up in this deadly confrontation?

English: You have not completed SIGNAL VOID.
You have not completed BURIED ECHOES.
An old piece of airfield paperwork.

Re: Field 31 Search and Rescue Upgrades

Hey crew,

As you know, we’ve been asked to provide SAR coverage for the rest of Great Bear. We’re tapping into the existing radio transmitter system but it’s pretty old. The TRANSMITTER TOWERS are scattered all over the lower island, including one we jury-rigged right here at the Field 31 Tower. The transmitter boxes are a bit prone to breaking down, but when powered and in good working order, each Tower can cover a decent range. Well beyond the region it’s located in.

Update your survey maps with the Transmitter sites in:

--Forlorn Muskeg
--Mystery Lake
--Milton

Expect to do annual maintenance. The WIRING and BATTERIES seem particularly fragile, and we’ve had some trouble with FUSES as well.

Testing continues, but initial reports have picked up some SIGNAL INTERFERENCE unusual transmissions in the following locations in Lower Great Bear:

* In Bleak Inlet, home of the old Cannery site
* Pleasant Valley, but we haven’t determined where
* Somewhere in the Hushed River Valley

Without these Transmitters working, we’ll have a hell of a time locating any transponder signals from crashed planes or whatever, so we need to stay on top of this.

Signed,

Captain Redrick, 14th Wing, SAR
An entry in an old logbook.

The island hasn’t been making our lives any easier. Hauling loads from the coast to the inland bases has been slow and costly. And people are starting to notice our operation around the Airfield and Mine. It's getting harder to stay under the radar.

 But the character of the locals, both here and far inland, seems in our favour.
 There aren’t any helping hands. Outsiders get ignored and then forgotten.

 And we play the part.
An entry in an old logbook.

The mine is a real shithole. If my job is to shepherd the men, then their job is to keep the roof from landing on all of us. But this week we found a decent chamber to start building Rüdiger's gadget.

 Teams 1 and 2 are with the program, but on shaky ground. Team 3 is getting volatile again. While it’s unclear what they have planned, I’ve called for additional security to fly in immediately. The Medical Officer has been conducting alignment interviews and has made some troubling observations.

 I’m still considering the implications, both for the men as well as project viability. My hope is the crew can keep their shit together long enough to finish phase one, and we can get out of this godforsaken place.

 It's starting to get to me.
An entry in an old logbook.

We ran power to Rüdiger's machine for the first time yesterday. It was nothing like what they predicted, even at half-energy.

 I still have no idea what the endgame for all of this will be. The whole project. And I’m seeing now that few of the men building it do either. It’s all over their faces. All this time underground isn’t helping their morale, but I’m confident our fragile truce will hold until we’re finished.

 We worked hard to make it this far after what happened to Team 3.

 But afterwards? Impossible to say.
An entry in an old logbook.

Whatever happened here, it’s not a virus, or any known pathogen. At least, that's what the doctor tells me. There are no visible injuries, only invisible ones.
 My symptoms have just started, but they track what the others have gone through. Things are starting to get fuzzy, just like with them.

 Faces I can’t remember. Like an old photo, blurry around the edges. Crumbling.

The few men left up here can’t be trusted to care for themselves. We've had to lock them in their quarters to keep them from wandering off. We tried going a different way, more psychological. We had a little luck at first, and then it all collapsed again.

 Rüdiger hasn’t been back to see us since we took the machine offline. I’m struggling myself, and holding out for the resupply he promised. Will it get here in time?

 I've changed, somehow. The men, the medical officer, all of us. But not him. Not Rüdiger

He’ll want the research. It shows some bizarre benefits, even if it’s come at a price. Rüdiger found what he was looking for.

 He can keep it.
A printout of a medical consultation.

Q: Session 14, Project Medical Officer interviewing Patient 7.
 Return to the first instance. What did you see?

 A: It was at the beach. Just pictures in my head, feelings.

 One of those beaches where the sand goes way down to the water, no drop off.
 I remember a... a grey day and dark water. No wind, no waves.

 I was alone...looking around a lot. I didn’t understand what was happening.

 Wha...what do you think when you’re that little? Always wondered why it was that day, that trip that stuck with me.

 Q: Focus on the ending, the final frame.

 A: They lost me...just a little kid.
A printout of a medical consultation.

Q: Session 5, Project Medical Officer interviewing Patient 7.
 Let’s visit the second instance again, first occurrence. What do you remember?

A: Uh...the sun was out, but it was cold at the river’s edge. There was a group of us that day.

 Ha..lots of laughing. Yelling. Summer in our heads.

Ha ha...no one was getting in the water. I guess I liked being first.

 I didn’t even jump, just, hrmph...slipped in quietly away from everybody.

Uh the water was clear but...bitter cold. I thought the bottom...was closer.

My head went under right away. God, I was a lousy swimmer.

 Uh...no one noticed me struggling in the...in the deep pool.

 Q: Carry on from where you were last session. Find the ending sequence. What do you see?

 A: Ah...my hand reaching for a flat, grey stone at the water’s edge. I...I grabbed it, I pulled my head out of the freezing water. A breath. The sun was shining through the trees...above us. Was...

 Was the sun out…? I thought...ah, the rain…no, no, no. That wasn’t it.

 Q: Keep hold of that image. It’s OK if it fades a little. Breathe. Try going again. Second instance.
A printout of a medical consultation.

Q: Session 12, Project Medical Officer interviewing Patient 7.
 Back to the third instance. Find the bridge between them.

 A: Trying to. Hrmph...ok.

It starts the same as every other time. A dark room, square. I feel the wall behind me and I can barely make out the walls to the right and left. Smooth, like steel or glass.

 I can’t see the wall opposite me...it’s too dim.

 I walk forward and that’s when I notice it. Every time. The pit.

 Just...uh, a hole in the floor, really. Haha. It’s funny, the floor seems to slope a little bit as it reaches the edge.

 But the floor is made of bricks. Bricks that start to bend. Best I can tell.

 Q: And the end? The last image you can remember?

 A: That’s when it shows up.

 Q: What shows up? Can you describe it?

 A: Hmm...from across the pit, where the other wall should be. Something...darker than everything around it. Sort of...floating?

 It moves to the edge of the hole. No face, just a moving shape. Uh...a shadow.
 Is it me? My face? Goddammit.

 And that’s when I wake up. Every damn time.
A printout of a medical consultation.

Entry 17, Project Medical Officer.

 We have attempted various psychological interventions with the team members.
 Interviews reveal that the deeper the recall exercise, the greater the distortion. Consolidation failures appear in each patient, no matter the subject content.

 So far, these have yielded little actionable data.

 We do, however, hold out hope for a treatment strategy to apply away from their work environment. Proximity to the site of exposure is my last, best guess.

 Behavioural changes are becoming more alarming. I will be including the following transcript excerpt in my summary report, to be filed with project leads before team extraction (should it occur):

–

Q: We’re almost finished. Please stay calm. Where has your mind settled then? Focus on the last image please.

 A: We just wanted to get out...to burn it all down. Or did we? Ha. I had it there, but I lost it again…I can’t remember what it was.

 He said he’d stand with us if something went wrong.

 Wha...what did we do? What did they make us do? They can’t get away with this.

 –

 End recording.
A Polaroid tucked into the Security Chief's logbook.
The locals call this the Enduring Waterfall. Wanted to capture the view from my usual spot.

Was our first day back down below since the boss and his people arrived.

He called us together and had us all sign new paperwork. Boilerplate stuff, but it had us wondering. What’s changed?

Then he gave a speech, as he likes to do. Only this time in front of the gadget. I was almost convinced, but then again I’ve never been practical enough to see what’s good for me.

He talked for a long time, but in the end we were able to restart our work on the machine’s electrical system. We also stabilized the track connecting the top of the Concentrator to the ridge above. Makes access easier if we need to move in more generators. This thing needs all the juice we can find.

Did I mention I need to get the hell out of here?

All our temporary scaffolding is coming apart now. Earthquakes and nervous hands will do that.

The final cables are set and insulated. We still don’t know if it’s enough.

The generators they brought in could power a small town through the winter.

Their latest big idea is to bring some kind of doctor in. Just to talk, they said.

None of the guys on my team believe a word of it.

Ever since we flipped the switch on that machine, no one seems settled. We want to get paid, sure. But we want to make it out of his hole in the ground, too.

I’ve gotta put a stop to this.

We’re just waiting now. I’ve been walking the tunnels, up and down. Air’s getting bad again.

Just scribblin’ these reports. Not sure why, though. Not anymore.

It’s like they turned the lights off in my head. All dark.

Where’d it all go?
A key from Langston Mine's Cold War era. «First Aid» is faintly visible in raised letters.
A faded piece of paper covered in fine handwriting.

In every man’s journey there is a moment of total clarity. When a blue sky or an empty road shows the way forward.

I have had several moments like this during my life. But they always carried with them a spark of unpredictability. An energy I did not control.

Was it these moments, these great creases in time that brought me my wealth? My success? My institutions and engines of influence and power? I have explored many corners of the planet, and subjected myself to many dangerous and foolish undertakings seeking the answers to these questions.

And I survived. Often in spite of myself and my ambition to define the absolute edges of my own existence.

But as the wheel of my life makes its final turn, I have decided they are the wrong questions altogether.

I am making new questions and with them, new answers. New knowledge.

A different world is coming. I am certain of it. And I will be prepared.

It is only a matter of WHEN, and it is in uncovering the WHEN that I will define my own moment.

Once again.

I have seen the new horizon.
Human bones, weathered by time and memory.
An entry in an old logbook.

If this message has reached you, it means they made it out, and to the Mainland.

What a mess, old friend. I sent them your way after we managed to get a chopper flight-worthy.

By now they shared my old call sign with you, from the Alaska days. I hope that, and this note from my logbook, convinces you. Do you recognize the book? Do you remember it?

It's gone bad over here, and strange beyond everything. But it's on me now. And there are others still missing down below.

Take care, and keep an eye on the horizon. You never know.

-- Vertasky
An entry in an old logbook.

I can probably make it back to the surface before the weather turns again. Moving slowly now.

Recording as much as I can, the writing helps keep me here. Otherwise my mind wanders.

To the sea. To small ships and deep water. My mother’s voice.
An entry in an old logbook.

…I’m never leaving this place. I see that now. I tried to reason with him, to get him to see what this had all cost us. Rüdiger had other plans. The transmission site over the mountains. He’s always had a way out, always. He risked nothing.

So I came back down. To try and smash this thing. Or do something.

Anything.

I think I’ll just close my eyes for a little while.
An entry in an old logbook.

I wanted to see you again. I wanted to feel your hand on my hip, your smile in my eyes.


I can’t picture what this thing is without that. Or you.


Everything is fading away here. I can’t remember.


The only thing I know is if I write it down it might get to you. Some way.

This mine is a graveyard. Maybe my own too, if I’m not careful. The wolves here are unwell. All this pollution in the ground. Awful.

Whatever happened, it goes beyond any of the stories Poppy told me about Langston Corp and the bad old days of uranium extraction.

I don’t even know how to say it. There’s a deeper darkness, some other mystery buried in those tunnels.

I couldn't access the lowest levels without suffocating, but there seems to be a clear path to try down there. I just need some way to manage the toxic vapours seeping out of the ground. There’s also the bizarre area locked away inside the entrance off the upper tracks, behind the derelict concentrator facility.

And there’s that downed helicopter in the hills above the old water extraction ponds I need to check out. Might be some tools to scavenge there, or in the concentrator and headframe building.

For now, a moment to rest.
Technical Backpack Equipped - Carrying Capacity Increased
Nynorsk: Tok på teknisk ransel - Auka bereevne

English: A sturdier Backpack with all the bells and whistles. You can carry more gear before becoming Encumbered.
Nynorsk: Nymotens ransel med tallause lommer. Du kan no bera meir før du vert nedtyngja.

English: Heavy down-filled parka made using high-end materials. Warm and rugged. The kind of parka worn by people who know what they're doing.
Nynorsk: Tung dunanorakk laga av kvalitetsmaterialar. Varm og slitesterk. Ein anorakk for folk som veit kva dei driv med.

English: Short-sleeved cotton t-shirt. Doesn't offer much warmth, particularly when wet.
Nynorsk: Korterma-skjorte av bomull. Gjev ikkje mykje varme, spesielt ikkje når han er våt.

Notes: Shown on HUD to incdicate build is a test version

English: Lower quality textures look worse but may perform better.
Nynorsk: Teksturar av lågare kvalitet vil kanskje sjå verre ut, men ytinga kan verta betre.

English: Sets the amount of memory available for textures.
Thin-knit wool sweater. Mostly for looks, but provides some warmth and being knit from wool remains warm when wet.
Nynorsk: Tynn ullgenser. Den passar best når du skal pynte deg, men den gjev òg litt varme. Ulla gjera at ein ikkje vert kald når ein vert våt.

Notes: This is displayed when the player wants to dismantle a snow shelter.
How long it will take to harvest something
UI label to show the time remaining when crafting an item with their best tool

English: Can be used for crafting and repair after air-drying indoors for {time-value}.
Nynorsk: Kan nyttast til å vøla og laga ting etter lufttuking inne i {time-value}.

English: A small plug or bundle of flammable material (paper, wool, cloth, dry bark or needles, etc.) required to start a fire.
Nynorsk: Ein liten bunt av brennbart materiale som ein treng for å laga eld.

English: Leave at an ice fishing hole to catch fish unattended. Can also be set with Bait or a Lure.
Nynorsk: Sett i eit isfiskehol for å fiske utan tilsyn. Kan nyttast i lag med både agn og sluk.

English: A rich, sweet-smelling soup. Eat it hot and it'll warm your heart. Might even stave off starvation for a little longer.
Nynorsk: Ein tjukk suppe som luktar søtt. Eit han varm og lat han varma hjartet ditt. Den kan til og med halde svolten i sjakk.

English: You can't focus on Research when you're this Cold.
Nynorsk: Du er for kald til å konsentrera deg.
Det er for mørkt til å lesa.

English: Too far away to paint here
Too far away to place object
Nynorsk: For langt vekke til å plassera

English: You can't focus on Research when you're this Hungry.
Nynorsk: Du er for svolten til å konsentrera deg.

English: A high-quality belt to lighten the load. Perfectly balanced to ensure all-day comfort and stability.

Nynorsk: Du må ha eit reiskap for å knusa isen

English: You can't focus on Research when you're this Thirsty.
Nynorsk: Du er for tyrst til å konsentrera deg.

English: You can't focus on Research when you're this Tired.
Nynorsk: Du er for trøytt til å konsentrera deg.

English: It's too windy to sustain this fire.
Nynorsk: Det er for mykje vind for dette bålet.
For mykje vind til å kveikja ei fyrstikk
For mykje vind til å kveikja fakkelen.

English: You can't focus on Research when your Condition is this compromised.
Nynorsk: Du har for dårleg helse til å konsentrera deg.

English: Knitted wool cap. Canadian style. Pronounced: "tuke".
A simple torch -- the same kind that's dispelled the darkness for thousands of years. Might even keep the Wolves at bay.
Nynorsk: Ein enkel fakkel, den same som har jaga vekk mørkeret i tusenvis av år. Kan til og med halde ulvane vekke.

Notes: as in the total of several values added together
wooden foot bridge in Broken RailRoad region

English: A backpack full of supplies presumably stashed here by the Forest Talkers.
Nynorsk: Ein ransel full av forsyningar, sannsynlegvis lagt igjen av Skogpratarane.

Notes: used when transitioning from one region to another
on-screen text for when the player is about to travel to the Kosedalen region from another region

English: Cannot carry Travois into this area
Nynorsk: Kan ikkje dra kjelken bort her
Kan ikkje dra kjelken over kanten
Legg ned kjelken for å handsama innhaldet

English: Cannot carry Travois on steep slopes
Nynorsk: Kan ikkje dra kjelken i bratte bakkar

English: You cannot interact with the Travois while crouching here
Nynorsk: Kan ikkje handsama kjelken medan du krøkjer deg her

English: A timeless and efficient way to drag loads over long distances. Take care to remember there are some places a Travois can't travel. Can be collapsed for convenient carrying, when empty.
Nynorsk: Ein tradisjonell kjelke orginalt nytta av urfolk i amerika. Med denne kan du trekkja med deg ekstra last, men hugs at du ikkje kan slepa han med deg overalt. Kan brettast i saman når han er tom.

English: That treatment did not do anything
Notes: Warning message showing when using a medicatgion and it had no effect

English: Reducing this distance is better for performance but will mean trees in the distance don't look as good.
Nynorsk: Å redusere denne avstanden gjev betre yting, men gjer òg at tre i bakgrunnen ikkje ser like fine ut.

English: A flavorful stew made from the ubiquitous, colourful fish.

Notes: will look like "Trust Value (0)" or "Trust Value (+15)"

English: Select the Bear Spear from the Radial Menu, then press and hold {Fire} to Set the Spear against a charging Bear, as long as you have enough Stamina.
Notes: How to use the Bear Spear, a tool/weapon you can acquire in The Long Dark's story mode, WINTERMUTE.

English: Hold {Fire} to Set the Spear, but watch your Stamina.
Notes: How to use the Bear Spear, a tool/weapon you can acquire in The Long Dark's story mode, WINTERMUTE.
How to use the Bear Spear, a tool/weapon you can acquire in The Long Dark's story mode, WINTERMUTE.

English: Resting restores lost Condition and helps you recover from Afflictions. You can Rest in beds you find as you explore the world. A Bedroll allows you to Rest whenever you like. Remember that Resting uses up Calories and the hours that pass make you Hungry and Thirsty. Resting also Saves your game.
Nynorsk: Kvile gjer at du kjem til hektene igjen, og at lidingar lækjast. Du kan kvile i senger som du finn underveis. Viss du har ein sovepose, kan du kvile kvar som helst. Husk at kvile forbrenn kaloriar, og at du vert både svolten og tyrst. Spelet lagrast når du kviler.

English: Rest in a bed or Bedroll to restore Condition.
Resting Heals You and Saves Your Progress
Nynorsk: Kvile gjer deg frisk og lagrar spelet.

English: Prepare Birch Bark before brewing it into a natural tea. Drink to gradually restore some lost Condition.
Notes: A tutorial explaining the effects of Birch Bark Tea, an item you can craft in The Long Dark.

English: Collect and prepare Birch Bark to brew a restorative tea.
Birch Bark Tea gradually restores a small amount of Condition
Marine Flares burn with a bright blue flame, and are louder than the red variant. These flares are especially effective in keeping Timberwolves at bay.
Marine Flares can be effective against Timberwolves.

To fix the elevator check for any nearby broken Fuse boxes. If the elevator electrical circuit can be completed maybe it will function again. You may need to replace burned out Fuses with replacements.
To fix the elevator check for any nearby broken Fuse boxes.
Find replacement Fuses for inactive Fuse boxes. These can be taken from other working Fuse boxes.
Notes: Найдите годные сменные предохранители для неисправного электрощитка. Взять их можно в других электрощитках.

English: Move replacement Fuses into inactive Fuse boxes to make them work.
If you need somewhere to sleep, don't have a bedroll and there are no beds or vehicles nearby, then check the caves - maybe there's something that could provide an improvised sleeping surface?
